description: This course covers the exam objectives of EC-Council's Certified Incident Handler (ECIH) program.  It discusses the basic skills to handle and respond to security events and addresses various underlying principles and techniques for detecting and responding to current and emerging computer security threats.
descriptionMD: This course covers the exam objectives of EC-Council's Certified Incident Handler (ECIH) program.  It discusses the basic skills to handle and respond to security events and addresses various underlying principles and techniques for detecting and responding to current and emerging computer security threats.
name: ECIH
subtitle: EC-Council Certified Incident Handler

episodes.description: This course covers the exam objectives of EC-Council's Certified Incident Handler (ECIH) program. It discusses the basic skills to handle and respond to security events and addresses various underlying principles and techniques for detecting and responding to current and emerging computer security threats.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.700
[SOUND]
>> If you're studying for

2
00:00:04.700 --> 00:00:07.830
the ECIH exam, you're in the perfect
place to learn more about it.

3
00:00:07.830 --> 00:00:10.550
Because right now,
Adam Gordon is going to go ahead and

4
00:00:10.550 --> 00:00:13.510
explain, well,
what to expect within this show series.

5
00:00:13.510 --> 00:00:15.140
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

6
00:00:15.140 --> 00:00:16.190
>> Thank you.

7
00:00:16.190 --> 00:00:16.810
Hello, everybody.

8
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:17.790
Hopefully everyone's doing well.

9
00:00:17.790 --> 00:00:19.690
Looking forward to spending time with you.

10
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:23.660
When we talk about the EC Council
Certified Incident Handler material,

11
00:00:23.660 --> 00:00:26.810
what we're really focusing on is
the understanding of what it means to

12
00:00:26.810 --> 00:00:30.520
be an incident responder,
an incident handler, an incident manager.

13
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:34.470
As an IT security professional, we're
gonna be talking about the methodology,

14
00:00:34.470 --> 00:00:37.370
the techniques,
the thought process, the tools and

15
00:00:37.370 --> 00:00:40.260
the strategies associated
with incident handling and

16
00:00:40.260 --> 00:00:45.020
incident response in the enterprise or in
the organizations that you all represent.

17
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:46.750
We'll be talking about
things like risk assessment.

18
00:00:46.750 --> 00:00:48.420
Why is risk so important?

19
00:00:48.420 --> 00:00:50.480
What does risk have to do
with incident handling?

20
00:00:50.480 --> 00:00:52.330
Well, come on back and talk to us and

21
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:54.210
we'll be happy to talk
about that with you.

22
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.590
What about instant response and
handling steps?

23
00:00:56.590 --> 00:01:01.310
What about the concept of the CERT,
the C, E, R, T, the CSIRT, C, S, I, R,

24
00:01:01.310 --> 00:01:05.270
T, computer security instant response,
computer emergency response.

25
00:01:05.270 --> 00:01:07.180
We'll define and talk about these terms.

26
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:10.840
We're gonna talk about how to handle
network and security related incidents.

27
00:01:10.840 --> 00:01:13.380
How to handle malicious code incidents.

28
00:01:13.380 --> 00:01:15.610
What happens when somebody
infects us with malware?

29
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:17.290
How do we address those concerns?

30
00:01:17.290 --> 00:01:21.220
How do we handle insider threats when
somebody that we work with perhaps is

31
00:01:21.220 --> 00:01:25.650
the threat source, the bad actor, that is
engaging in activity that leads to risk?

32
00:01:25.650 --> 00:01:26.510
How do we address that?

33
00:01:26.510 --> 00:01:27.690
How do we find that out?

34
00:01:27.690 --> 00:01:30.320
Come back and join us, and
we'll be talking more about that.

35
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:32.490
Forensic analysis and incident response.

36
00:01:32.490 --> 00:01:36.500
How do we know, once we find out
that there's been an incident and

37
00:01:36.500 --> 00:01:40.270
we have evidence that points us in that
direction, how do we deal with that?

38
00:01:40.270 --> 00:01:43.750
And how do we capture that evidence
in a way that allows us to establish

39
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:46.870
beyond reasonable doubt a chain
of custody of evidence?

40
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:49.550
And the ability to handle that evidence so
that if and

41
00:01:49.550 --> 00:01:55.050
when it is necessary to show up in a court
of law and to describe what we found,

42
00:01:55.050 --> 00:01:58.710
and to testify as to the events
that occurred, we could do so

43
00:01:58.710 --> 00:02:02.170
authoritatively and we can stand on
the evidence that we have captured and

44
00:02:02.170 --> 00:02:05.180
we have cataloged,
we have reported on, we have analyzed.

45
00:02:05.180 --> 00:02:07.370
Because we've done so
in a forensically sound way.

46
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:09.130
We'll talk about incident reporting,
incident recovery.

47
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:10.460
And of course, topic near and

48
00:02:10.460 --> 00:02:13.780
dear to my heart and Cherokee's,
we'll be talking about security policy and

49
00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:17.800
law and the impact of policy and
law on the incident handling profession.

50
00:02:17.800 --> 00:02:20.460
Encourage you to all come on back,
take a look at all that with us.

51
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:21.500
Spend some time with us.

52
00:02:21.500 --> 00:02:24.270
And as always,
make sure that you are selective and

53
00:02:24.270 --> 00:02:27.910
watch what you want to understand and
find out about in this series of episodes.

54
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:30.660
But keep in mind, there may be a part one,
part two, part three.

55
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:34.350
We often encourage you to watch
those episodes in sequential order.

56
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:36.600
If you missed something,
go back and watch them again.

57
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:37.520
That's why we're record them and

58
00:02:37.520 --> 00:02:39.860
why you can play them back
whenever you wanna look at them.

59
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:41.200
Looking forward to spending time with you.

60
00:02:41.200 --> 00:02:43.400
As always, please come on back and see us.

61
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:46.340
And when you do,
make sure you bring comfy clothes.

62
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:47.542
What did you say, popcorn?

63
00:02:47.542 --> 00:02:50.430
>> Popcorn. [LAUGH] >> Bring popcorn and
bring a notepad and make some notes and

64
00:02:50.430 --> 00:02:52.050
write down all those
things that are important.

65
00:02:52.050 --> 00:02:53.694
And make sure that as you're doing so

66
00:02:53.694 --> 00:02:56.559
you thinking about how you're
gonna prepare for this exam and or

67
00:02:56.559 --> 00:03:00.061
the information necessary to relay this
to your professional field, and to do

68
00:03:00.061 --> 00:03:03.669
this in the real world as you look to
become more educated, more knowledgeable,

69
00:03:03.669 --> 00:03:07.097
and of course, more valuable to your
organization as an incident handler.

70
00:03:08.527 --> 00:03:11.798
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin their foray into another great EC-Council certification, the Certified Incident Handler(E|CIH). They kick things off by discussing the foundational knowledge inherent to any CIH. This includes defining a security incident, classifying assets and data, and explaining some of the not-so-glamorous aspects of the job.
episodes.title: Intro to Incident Response

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion on foundational topic pertinent to the Certified Incident Handler(E|CIH) exam. They pick back up by defining terms such as Information Owner/System/Custodian/Warfare, the CIA triad (Confidentiality/Integrity/Availability), and Risk assessment.
episodes.title: Intro to Incident Response Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their introduction to Incident Response by defining more terms and discussing the role that an Incident Handler plays. They explore terms like Attack, Risk, Threat, Threat Source, and Vulnerability as well as Types of Incidents.
episodes.title: Intro to Incident Response Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish laying down the foundational information needed with regards to Incident Response and specifically the E|CIH exam. They wrap things up by talking more about Incident prioritization and then examining what an Incident Response looks like exactly.
episodes.title: Intro to Incident Response Part 4

topics.title: Introduction to Incident Response and Handling

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam start their discussion about Risk and Risk Management with regards to Incident Response/Handling. They begin by defining Risk, examining 2 common formulas for calculating Risk. Then they describe the 7 steps involved in Risk Management and look at some resources to help you get your finger on the pulse of Risk in context of Incident Response.
episodes.title: Risk

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion about Risk and Risk Management with regards to Incident Response/Handling. They pick back up by looking at the in's and out's of Risk Assessment. They also show you many types of Risk Matrixes and Methodologies for performing Risk Assessments.
episodes.title: Risk Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam further their conversation about Risk and Risk Management, here jumping back in by explaining the 5 steps involved in the risk assessment of the work place. Then they give you an overview of Risk Analysis, including common approaches, both qualitative and quantitative, Risk controls and implementation, as well as strategies for addressing risk.
episodes.title: Risk Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate the PILAR tool which is used by Risk Analysts and Incident Handlers to perform Risk analysis and management.
episodes.title: Risk Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain the common Incident Response steps. They start by explaining how to identify an incident and then the three functions of Incident Handling. Then they explore the goals of the Incident Response Team or Handlers.
episodes.title: Incident Response Steps

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue explaining the process or steps of Incident Response. They jump back in by looking at the details about an Incident Response Plan's creation and implementation. They start down a lengthy list of steps, beginning with Identification, Incident Recording, Initial Response, Communicating the Incident, Containment, Formulating a Response Strategy, Incident Classification, and Incident Investigation.
episodes.title: Incident Response Steps Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue walking you through the many steps involved with an Incident Response plan, beginning with Data Collection, Forensic Analysis, Evidence Protection, Notifying External Agencies, Eradication, Systems Recovery, Incident Documentation, Incident Damage and Cost Assessment, Review and Update Response Policies.
episodes.title: Incident Response Steps Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam move forward with their discussion about Incident Response and the steps thereof, here focusing on the Incident Management phase. They go through the activities that are part and partial to Incident Management like vulnerability analysis, system recovery, and others. Also discussed includes IM process steps, IM Team membership, and relationships inside of the Incident ecosystem.
episodes.title: Incident Response Steps Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain the details and makeup of a Computer Security Incident Response Team(CSIRT). They explore the purpose, goals, and strategies of the CSIRT as well as their constituency and best practice steps for CSIRT creation.
episodes.title: CSIRT

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion about Computer Security Incident Response Teams. Specific topics covered include: CSIRT Roles, Services, Policies and Procedures, and Case Management.
episodes.title: CSIRT Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion about Computer Security Incident Response Teams. Here they draw distinctions between CSIRTs and CERTs, really diving into what makes up a Computer Emergency Response Team and how they employ the Operationally Critical Threat, Asset, and Vulnerability Evaluation or OCTAVE methodology.
episodes.title: CSIRT Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore some of the common threats that an Incident Handler might encounter. The first type of attack that they cover is the Denial of Service(DoS) and Distributed Denial of Service(DDoS). They look at the possible response strategies as well as ways to handle the DDoS incident.
episodes.title: Network Security Incidents

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore some of the common threats that an Incident Handler might encounter. Here they discuss how to handle unauthorized access as an incident, exploring what unauthorized access looks like and then how to prepare for those types of attacks. Also covered is inappropriate system usage.
episodes.title: Network Security Incidents Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore some of the common threats that an Incident Handler might encounter. Here they take the time to explore some of the tools that may be found in a CIH's tool-bag. These include tools such as: SAINT, Nessus, ngrep, Wireshark, and NMAP.
episodes.title: Network Security Incidents Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk through the common types of malware that a CIH will have to deal with during any given incident. These malware types include Viruses, Worms, Spyware, and Trojans. Then they discuss how to identify whether a client is infected and then the steps taken to handle these incidents.
episodes.title: Malicious Code Incidents

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam dive into handling insider threat incidents.
episodes.title: Insider Threats

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam are back to discuss more about insider threats, specifically looking into some of the tools and/or techniques like a keylogger that an insider may employ to attack an environment.
episodes.title: Insider Threats Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore forensic analysis from the perspective of a CIH. They start by defining what computer forensics is and present a methodology for implementation. Then they explain the types of computer forensics, the computer forensics process, and even look at forensics tools like Helix for performing an investigation.
episodes.title: Forensic Analysis and Incident Response

episodes.description: Watch Adam and Cherokee define and discuss digital evidence. Adam gives us 5 Be's to help us remember important characteristics of digital evidence. Collecting digital evidence in the order of volatility is a must because precious evidence may be lost if power is lost. Also, it is important not to rewrite any information present. Adam gives us some tools to help create copies which can be used for analysis.
episodes.title: Forensic Analysis and Incident Response Part 2

episodes.description: In this show Adam and Cherokee clarify important details to include within your incident report. Details are essential when it comes to incident reporting. Even details that may seem minuscule such as noting any time off sets can significantly impact your investigation. Adam also references US-CERT event categories to help create standardization.
episodes.title: Incident Reporting

episodes.description: In this show Adam and Cherokee converse over incident recovery steps such as restoration, system validation, system operations, and system monitoring. Next, they speak on import plans to have in place to prepare an organization for when an incident occurs. Additionally, Adam explains and dissects all that is involved with a Continuity of Operations Plan. Lastly, he offers steps to create a successful Incident Recovery Planning process.
episodes.title: Incident Recovery

episodes.description: This show Adam and Cherokee lay down the Law so to speak. They discuss how polices and law impact an organization's infrastructure. Adam provides characteristics of a good security policy in addition to where to find good templates. They also address issues to consider when involving external entities. Adam explains how the fourth Amendment impacts obtaining information through a warrant-less search. Lastly, Adam answers Cherokee's question regarding ones reasonable expectation of privacy.
episodes.title: Security Policy and Law

episodes.description: This is a continuation of the discussion with Adam and Cherokee. They are showcasing Security Policy and Law. They continue to dissect The Fourth Amendment stating a private individual may perform an investigation on their own accord then relinquishing the results to authorities. Examples such as Unites States v. Jacobsen and whistle-blowers such as Snowden relate to these concepts. Lastly, Adam explains the statutes under the Privacy Protection Act.
episodes.title: Security Policy and Law Part 2
